children.subject: 44th percentile was in relation to the curve already, not 44% on MT1 and mt2 combined. Any tips for studying to do good on the final?
Yeah, if the grade was to be determined right now, being 44th percentile would put you around the B/B+ border. As for tips for the final, I'm not the person you should be asking haha.

As an aside, (and hopefully this helps cheer you up a little bit more), 44th percentile or so is usually B/B+ border nowadays, so if you do around average on final you'll probably have a B+. That may push you closer to the 3.3 cutoff and give you a better chance to petition and declare.

Although I don't know much about declaring, I can give you some pointers on how to study for the CS 70 final to do well:

1. Review every single proof. Memorize them. You need intuition to solve the CS 70 problems. This doesn't come from out of the blue. By knowing more proofs and how more problems were approached, you will be able to improve.

2. Probability. The biggest part of the CS 70 final is probability. If you have been keeping up with the homework and actually thinking about the questions, it will give you a leg up in the exam. If not, review all the homework problems and understand how to solve them (don't just understand the solution, but the approach as well). Be confident taking integrals and derivatives to convert from CDF and PDF. Know the various distributions by heart.

3. Cheat sheet. Be sure to include Markov's/Chebyshev's Inequality and CLT. Be sure to write down the CDF, PDFs, variances, and means of all the distributions you covered. This will help you a lot.

It’s definitely very possible to declare with a 3.2- make sure to highlight in your appeal:

1) why you want to pursue CS and what you’ve done to pursue that passion outside of just classes - clubs? Internships? Research? Outreach work? Etc etc 

2) what led you to not get to the 3.3 cutoff and how you’re going to mitigate/work around this in the future - are you just a bad test-taker, but you’re more interested in the project based upper division classes? Did you have any personal challenges in any of the semesters you were taking pre-reqs that affected your ability to perform? Etc etc 

the most important thing though is to stay focused and keep working hard and pushing until the very end. Anything can happen, so do your best to not worry about the consequences of getting X grade/percentile (even though it’s hard to do; trust me I get it!) until after final grades are out!! Keep your chin up, you got this!

- someone who declared with a 3.2 after getting destroyed  by 70’s exams

You can drop summer courses any time before the final without using up your emergency late drop. You won't get refunded however.

Source: Me, dropping 61C this summer after having already used up my one-time late drop earlier in the year.

If you haven't used your emergency drop (if you don't know what this look it up), I would say try your best to learn the material for the rest of the summer. If you're not confident you can do well on the final, it's okay. Just try again next semester. That's assuming you haven't used it yet tho

history.content:
Has anyone been able to declare cs with a 3.2 or 3.2 in cs 61a/? And 70? If so what was the process like and how we’re you able to get your cs declaration approved? 


Back story: im cs 70 this summer and I need an A- to declare but after the past 2 midterms, I’m only Round the 44th percentile which is B or B- range at the moment. Are there any tips from anyone to get to that A- level? I’ve taken all the cs lower divs, stat 134, and audited for a semester. Additionally, I’ve prepared by taking practice midterms so I don’t know what else I can do.  The past midterms really has me bummed and and I’ve lost motivation to do anything today
history.subject: Declaring with 3.3 gpa cap
